intelligence reports, Western government officials, scholarly research, and renowned journalists.<sup id="cite_ref-isis_180-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-isis-180">[180]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-how_181-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-how-181">[181]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-carn_182-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-carn-182">[182]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wsj.com_186-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wsj.com-186">[186]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-p_187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-p-187">[187]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-frank_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frank-188">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-pl_185-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pl-185">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dail_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dail-189">[189]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-terror_183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-terror-183">[183]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-extremism_184-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-extremism-184">[184]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2016.E2.80.93present:_Kuwait_Vision_2035"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2016–present:_Kuwait_Vision_2035">2016–present: Kuwait Vision 2035</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: 2016–present: Kuwait Vision 2035">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Since the mid-to-late 2010s, Kuwait has commenced a national development plan, <a href="https://ar.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D9%83%D9%88%D9%8A%D8%AA_%D8%AC%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%AF%D8%A9" class="extiw" title="ar:كويت جديدة">Kuwait Vision 2035</a>, to diversify the economy.<sup id="cite_ref-pip_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pip-33">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-spur_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-spur-190">[190]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-reg_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reg-191">[191]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-newkuw_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newkuw-35">[35]</a></sup> As a result, Kuwait's infrastructure market entered a new phase of growth.<sup id="cite_ref-ignited_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ignited-192">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Meed_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meed-193">[193]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-midst_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-midst-194">[194]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/MEED" title="MEED">MEED</a>, Kuwait was the region's largest spender of oil and gas megaprojects for two years.<sup id="cite_ref-projects_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-projects-41">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-watts_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-watts-195">[195]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-watts2_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-watts2-196">[196]</a></sup> Kuwait is currently the fourth largest infrastructure market in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-projects_41-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-projects-41">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-projects2_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-projects2-197">[197]</a></sup> China has been Kuwait's largest trade partner since 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-china2_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-china2-198">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-china3_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-china3-199">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-china4_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-china4-200">[200]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-newes_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newes-201">[201]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-china1_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-china1-202">[202]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jacckuwait.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Jacckuwait.jpg/220px-Jacckuwait.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Jacckuwait.jpg/330px-Jacckuwait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Jacckuwait.jpg/440px-Jacckuwait.jpg 2x" data-file-width="490" data-file-height="367"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jacckuwait.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Jaber_Al-Ahmad_Cultural_Centre" title="Sheikh Jaber Al-Ahmad Cultural Centre">Sheikh Jaber Al-Ahmad Cultural Centre</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-alb_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alb-203">[203]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As part of Kuwait Vision 2035, the <a href="/wiki/Amiri_Diwan_of_Kuwait" title="Amiri Diwan of Kuwait">Amiri Diwan</a> inaugurated the <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_National_Cultural_District" title="Kuwait National Cultural District">Kuwait National Cultural District</a> (KNCD), which comprises <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Abdullah_Al-Salem_Cultural_Centre" title="Sheikh Abdullah Al-Salem Cultural Centre">Sheikh Abdullah Al-Salem Cultural Centre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Jaber_Al-Ahmad_Cultural_Centre" title="Sheikh Jaber Al-Ahmad Cultural Centre">Sheikh Jaber Al-Ahmad Cultural Centre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Shaheed_Park" title="Al Shaheed Park">Al Shaheed Park</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Al_Salam_Palace_(Kuwait)" title="Al Salam Palace (Kuwait)">Al Salam Palace</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kncd2_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kncd2-204">[204]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kncd_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kncd-205">[205]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kncd3_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kncd3-206">[206]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-midst_194-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-midst-194">[194]</a></sup> With a capital cost of more than US$1&nbsp;billion, the project is one of the largest cultural investments in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-kncd_205-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kncd-205">[205]</a></sup> In November 2016, the Sheikh Jaber Al Ahmad Cultural Centre opened.<sup id="cite_ref-alb_203-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alb-203">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> It is the largest cultural centre and opera house in the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-newkuwait_34-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newkuwait-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-omnd_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-omnd-208">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-opsc_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-opsc-209">[209]</a></sup> The Abdullah Al-Salem Cultural Centre was inaugurated in early 2018, it was the world's largest single-delivery museum project.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto3_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-212">[212]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> The Kuwait National Cultural District is a member of the <a href="/wiki/Global_Cultural_Districts_Network" title="Global Cultural Districts Network">Global Cultural Districts Network</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gcdn_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gcdn-42">[42]</a></sup> The Amiri Diwan also opened <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Motor_Town" title="Kuwait Motor Town">Kuwait Motor Town</a> to place Kuwait at the forefront of world-class motorsport events.<sup id="cite_ref-kuwait_motor_town_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kuwait_motor_town-214">[214]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-motor_town_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-motor_town-215">[215]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Sabah_Al_Ahmad_Sea_City" title="Sabah Al Ahmad Sea City">Sabah Al Ahmad Sea City</a> was inaugurated in mid–2016.<sup id="cite_ref-twf_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-twf-216">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mill_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mill-218">[218]</a></sup> The city is considered a pioneering project in the region due to its environmentally sustainable construction techniques.<sup id="cite_ref-Ecology_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ecology-219">[219]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup> As part of Kuwait Vision 2035, Kuwait inaugurated its largest <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> park, Shagaya Renewable Energy Park, which includes concentrated solar power, solar photovoltaic, and wind power plants.<sup id="cite_ref-shagaya2_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shagaya2-221">[221]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-renewable_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-renewable-222">[222]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-shagaya_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shagaya-223">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-shagaya1_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shagaya1-224">[224]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sabah_Al_Ahmad_Sea_City_-_Phase_A3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Sabah_Al_Ahmad_Sea_City_-_Phase_A3.jpg/220px-Sabah_Al_Ahmad_Sea_City_-_Phase_A3.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Sabah_Al_Ahmad_Sea_City_-_Phase_A3.jpg/330px-Sabah_Al_Ahmad_Sea_City_-_Phase_A3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Sabah_Al_Ahmad_Sea_City_-_Phase_A3.jpg/440px-Sabah_Al_Ahmad_Sea_City_-_Phase_A3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="467"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sabah_Al_Ahmad_Sea_City_-_Phase_A3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Sabah_Al_Ahmad_Sea_City" title="Sabah Al Ahmad Sea City">Sabah Al Ahmad Sea City</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Under the <a href="/wiki/Belt_and_Road_Initiative" title="Belt and Road Initiative">Belt and Road Initiative</a>, Kuwait and China have many important cooperation projects including Al Mutlaa Residential City which is currently under construction in northern Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-mutlaa4_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mutlaa4-37">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mutlaa_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mutlaa-38">[38]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mutlaa2_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mutlaa2-39">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mutlaa3_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mutlaa3-225">[225]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Jaber_Al-Ahmad_Al-Sabah_Causeway" title="Sheikh Jaber Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah Causeway">Sheikh Jaber Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah Causeway</a> is part of the first phase of the <a href="/wiki/Madinat_al-Hareer" title="Madinat al-Hareer">Silk City</a> project.<sup id="cite_ref-bri_36-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bri-36">[36]</a></sup> The causeway was inaugurated in May 2019 as part of Kuwait Vision 2035,<sup id="cite_ref-north_vision_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-north_vision-226">[226]</a></sup> it connects Kuwait City to northern Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-north_vision_226-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-north_vision-226">[226]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bri_36-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bri-36">[36]</a></sup> With an estimated construction value of approximately US$3 billion,<sup id="cite_ref-:0_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-227">[227]</a></sup> it was one of the largest and most challenging infrastructure projects in the entire world.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_227-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-227">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nasa_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nasa-228">[228]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-north_vision_226-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-north_vision-226">[226]</a></sup> It crosses two <a href="/wiki/Artificial_islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Artificial islands">artificial islands</a> (Bay Island North and Bay Island South) which were constructed for entertainment and tourism purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-nasa_228-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nasa-228">[228]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the years leading up to the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> pandemic, Kuwait invested in its health care system at a rate that was proportionally higher than most other GCC countries.<sup id="cite_ref-health3_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health3-229">[229]</a></sup> As a result, the public hospital sector significantly increased its capacity.<sup id="cite_ref-health4_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health4-230">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-health5_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health5-231">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-health1_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health1-232">[232]</a></sup> Many new hospitals opened, Kuwait currently has 20 public hospitals.<sup id="cite_ref-health6_233-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health6-233">[233]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-health5_231-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health5-231">[231]</a></sup> The new Sheikh Jaber Al-Ahmad Hospital is the largest hospital in the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-health2_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health2-234">[234]</a></sup> Kuwait also has 16 private hospitals.<sup id="cite_ref-health4_230-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health4-230">[230]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In February 2020, Kuwait opened the Sheikh Jaber Al-Abdullah Al-Jaber Al-Sabah International Tennis Complex and launched the Rafa Nadal Academy Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-tennis_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tennis-235">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-pip_33-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pip-33">[33]</a></sup> The facility is the largest tennis academy in the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-tennis_235-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tennis-235">[235]</a></sup> There are various other major infrastructure projects.<sup id="cite_ref-zour5_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zour5-236">[236]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Al_Zour_Refinery" title="Al Zour Refinery">Al Zour Refinery</a> is the largest refinery in the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-zour1_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zour1-237">[237]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-zour2_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zour2-238">[238]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-zour3_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zour3-239">[239]</a></sup> Sulaibiya Wastewater Treatment Plant is the world's largest wastewater purification plant using membrane technology.<sup id="cite_ref-sulaibiya5_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sulaibiya5-240">[240]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sulaibiya2_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sulaibiya2-241">[241]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sulaibiya4_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sulaibiya4-242">[242]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sulaibiya3_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sulaibiya3-243">[243]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sulaibiya_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sulaibiya-244">[244]</a></sup> Umm Al Hayman Wastewater Treatment Plant is one of the world's largest ecologically sustainable sewage treatment plants.<sup id="cite_ref-uhw_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uhw-245">[245]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hog_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hog-246">[246]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait has an emerging <a href="/wiki/Kuwait#Space" title="Kuwait">space industry</a> driven by the private sector.<sup id="cite_ref-space_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-space-247">[247]</a></sup> Kuwait was the first country in the region to implement <a href="/wiki/5G" title="5G">5G</a> technology.<sup id="cite_ref-5g_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5g-248">[248]</a></sup> Kuwait is among the world's leading markets in 5G penetration.<sup id="cite_ref-5g_248-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5g-248">[248]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5gkw_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5gkw-249">[249]</a></sup> In September 2020, Kuwait's Crown Prince Sheikh <a href="/wiki/Nawaf_Al-Ahmad_Al-Jaber_Al-Sabah" title="Nawaf Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah">Nawaf Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah</a> became the 16th Emir of Kuwait and the successor to Emir Sheikh Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah, who died at the age of 91.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup> In October 2020, Sheikh <a href="/wiki/Mishal_Al-Ahmad_Al-Jaber_Al-Sabah" title="Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah">Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah</a> was appointed as the Crown Prince.<sup id="cite_ref-Al_Jazeera_2020_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al_Jazeera_2020-251">[251]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The new Sabah Al-Salem University City is one of the largest educational campuses in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[252]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_International_Airport" title="Kuwait International Airport">Kuwait International Airport</a> recently inaugurated <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_International_Airport#Terminals" title="Kuwait International Airport">two new terminals</a> to cater to <a href="/wiki/List_of_airlines_of_Kuwait" title="List of airlines of Kuwait">Kuwait-based airlines</a>. Moreover, the largest Kuwait International Airport terminal (Terminal 2) is currently under construction and will expand the airport's overall capacity by 25–50 million passengers per year.<sup id="cite_ref-t2_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-t2-253">[253]</a></sup> The new terminal is environmentally sustainable.<sup id="cite_ref-t2env_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-t2env-254">[254]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-t2_253-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-t2-253">[253]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Under China's <a href="/wiki/Belt_and_Road_Initiative" title="Belt and Road Initiative">Belt and Road Initiative</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mubarak_Al_Kabeer_Port" title="Mubarak Al Kabeer Port">Mubarak Al Kabeer Port</a> is part of the first phase of the <a href="/wiki/Madinat_al-Hareer" title="Madinat al-Hareer">Silk City</a> project.<sup id="cite_ref-beltroad2_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beltroad2-40">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bri_36-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bri-36">[36]</a></sup> As of 2021, the Mubarak Al Kabeer Port is currently under construction.<sup id="cite_ref-phase_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-phase-255">[255]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-constructionweek_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constructionweek-256">[256]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kun_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kun-257">[257]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-full_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-full-258">[258]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-date_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-date-259">[259]</a></sup> In September 2020, it was reported that the port is 53% complete.<sup id="cite_ref-completion_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-completion-260">[260]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> In March 2021, it was announced that Kuwait and Pakistan will develop linkages between <a href="/wiki/Gwadar_Port" title="Gwadar Port">Gwadar Port</a> and Mubarak Al Kabeer Port.<sup id="cite_ref-pk_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pk-262">[262]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-pka_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pka-263">[263]</a></sup> In April 2021, the port's first phase was completed (4 berths).<sup id="cite_ref-full_258-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-full-258">[258]</a></sup> As part of Mubarak Al Kabeer Port's development, <a href="/wiki/Bubiyan_Island" title="Bubiyan Island">Bubiyan Island</a> will contain power plants and substations.<sup id="cite_ref-boubyan_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-boubyan-264">[264]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-constructionweek_256-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constructionweek-256">[256]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mew_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mew-265">[265]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-elsew_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-elsew-266">[266]</a></sup> A 5,000-megawatt power plant has already been built in <a href="/wiki/Subiya,_Kuwait" title="Subiya, Kuwait">Subiya</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-suba_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-suba-267">[267]</a></sup> the Subiya power plant is the largest power plant in Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup> Mubarak Al Kabeer Port is among Kuwait's largest infrastructure projects in 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-april_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-april-271">[271]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-anba_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-anba-272">[272]</a></sup> There is a current road project connecting Mubarak Al Kabeer Port's first phase to the existing road network in Bubiyan Island.<sup id="cite_ref-road_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-road-273">[273]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-full_258-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-full-258">[258]</a></sup> Mubarak Al Kabeer Port's <a href="/wiki/Fire_station" title="Fire station">fire stations</a> are currently under development.<sup id="cite_ref-Fire_station_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fire_station-274">[274]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Geography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Kuwait" title="Geography of Kuwait">Geography of Kuwait</a> and <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Kuwait" title="Environmental issues in Kuwait">Environmental issues in Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1008px">
       <div class="thumbinner">
        <div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto">
         <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwait_City_banner.jpg" class="image" title="Skyline of Kuwait City, capital and largest city of Kuwait."><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Kuwait_City_banner.jpg/1000px-Kuwait_City_banner.jpg" decoding="async" width="1000" height="143" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Kuwait_City_banner.jpg/1500px-Kuwait_City_banner.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Kuwait_City_banner.jpg/2000px-Kuwait_City_banner.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5897" data-file-height="842"></a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwait_City_banner.jpg" title="File:Kuwait City banner.jpg"> </a>
         </div>Skyline of <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_City" title="Kuwait City">Kuwait City</a>, capital and largest city of Kuwait.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Satellite_image_of_Kuwait_in_November_2001.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Satellite_image_of_Kuwait_in_November_2001.jpg/220px-Satellite_image_of_Kuwait_in_November_2001.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="203" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Satellite_image_of_Kuwait_in_November_2001.jpg/330px-Satellite_image_of_Kuwait_in_November_2001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Satellite_image_of_Kuwait_in_November_2001.jpg/440px-Satellite_image_of_Kuwait_in_November_2001.jpg 2x" data-file-width="762" data-file-height="703"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Satellite_image_of_Kuwait_in_November_2001.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A satellite image of Kuwait reveals its desert topography.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwait_pol_06.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Kuwait_pol_06.jpg/220px-Kuwait_pol_06.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="252" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Kuwait_pol_06.jpg/330px-Kuwait_pol_06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Kuwait_pol_06.jpg/440px-Kuwait_pol_06.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1009" data-file-height="1155"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwait_pol_06.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Kuwait shares land borders with Iraq and Saudi Arabia, and maritime borders with Iraq, Saudi Arabia, and Iran.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Located in the north-east corner of the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a>, Kuwait is one of the smallest countries in the world in terms of land area. Kuwait lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/28th_parallel_north" title="28th parallel north">28°</a> and <a href="/wiki/31st_parallel_north" title="31st parallel north">31° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/46th_meridian_east" title="46th meridian east">46°</a> and <a href="/wiki/49th_meridian_east" title="49th meridian east">49° E</a>. Kuwait is generally low-lying, with the highest point being 306&nbsp;m (1,004&nbsp;ft) <a href="/wiki/Above_sea_level" class="mw-redirect" title="Above sea level">above sea level</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-3">[3]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait has <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Kuwait" title="List of islands of Kuwait">nine islands</a>, all of which, with the exception of <a href="/wiki/Failaka_Island" title="Failaka Island">Failaka Island</a>, are uninhabited.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[275]</a></sup> With an area of 860&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (330&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), the <a href="/wiki/Bubiyan_Island" title="Bubiyan Island">Bubiyan</a> is the largest island in Kuwait and is connected to the rest of the country by a 2,380-metre-long (7,808&nbsp;ft) bridge.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup> 0.6% of Kuwaiti land area is considered arable<sup id="cite_ref-cia_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-3">[3]</a></sup> with sparse vegetation found along its 499-kilometre-long (310&nbsp;mi) coastline.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-3">[3]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_City" title="Kuwait City">Kuwait City</a> is located on <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Bay" title="Kuwait Bay">Kuwait Bay</a>, a natural deep-water harbor. </p>
      <p>Kuwait's <a href="/wiki/Burgan_field" title="Burgan field">Burgan field</a> has a total capacity of approximately 70 billion barrels (11&nbsp;billion cubic metres) of proven oil reserves. During the 1991 <a href="/wiki/Kuwaiti_oil_fires" title="Kuwaiti oil fires">Kuwaiti oil fires</a>, more than 500 oil lakes were created covering a combined surface area of about <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style>35.7&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (<span class="frac" role="math">13<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">3</span>⁄<span class="den">4</span></span>&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup> The resulting soil contamination due to oil and soot accumulation had made eastern and south-eastern parts of Kuwait uninhabitable. Sand and oil residue had reduced large parts of the Kuwaiti desert to semi-asphalt surfaces.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup> The oil spills during the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a> also drastically affected Kuwait's marine resources.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Climate">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Kuwait" class="mw-redirect" title="Climate of Kuwait">Climate of Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Due to Kuwait's proximity to Iraq and Iran, the winter season in Kuwait is colder than other coastal countries in the Arabian Peninsula (especially UAE, Qatar, and Bahrain). Kuwait is also less humid than other coastal regions in the Arabian Peninsula. The spring season in March is warm with occasional thunderstorms. The frequent winds from the northwest are cold in winter and hot in summer. Southeasterly damp winds spring up between July and October. Hot and dry south winds prevail in spring and early summer. The shamal, a northwesterly wind common during June and July, causes dramatic sandstorms.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup> Summers in Kuwait are some of the hottest on earth. The highest recorded temperature was 54&nbsp;°C (129&nbsp;°F) at <a href="/wiki/Mitribah" title="Mitribah">Mitribah</a> on 21 July 2016, which is the highest temperature recorded in Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_carbon_dioxide_emissions_per_capita" title="List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions per capita">emits a lot of carbon dioxide per person</a> compared to other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[283]</a></sup> In 2014, Kuwait was the fourth highest country in the world in term of <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_carbon_dioxide_emissions_per_capita" title="List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions per capita">CO2 per capita emissions</a> after <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cura%C3%A7ao" title="Curaçao">Curaçao</a> and <a href="/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago" title="Trinidad and Tobago">Trinidad and Tobago</a> according to the World Bank.<sup id="cite_ref-test_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-test-284">[284]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Access to <a href="/wiki/Biocapacity" title="Biocapacity">biocapacity</a> in Kuwait is lower than world average. In 2016, Kuwait had 0.59 global hectares <sup id="cite_ref-footprintdata_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-footprintdata-285">[285]</a></sup> of biocapacity per person within its territory, much less than the world average of 1.6 global hectares per person.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup> In 2016 Kuwait used 8.6 global hectares of biocapacity per person - their <a href="/wiki/Ecological_footprint" title="Ecological footprint">ecological footprint</a> of consumption. This means they use about 14.5 times as much biocapacity as Kuwait contains. As a result, Kuwait is running a biocapacity deficit.<sup id="cite_ref-footprintdata_285-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-footprintdata-285">[285]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="National_parks">National parks</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: National parks">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>At present, there are five <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas" class="mw-redirect" title="Protected areas">protected areas</a> in Kuwait recognized by the <a href="/wiki/IUCN" class="mw-redirect" title="IUCN">IUCN</a>. In response to Kuwait becoming the <a href="/wiki/List_of_parties_to_the_Ramsar_Convention" title="List of parties to the Ramsar Convention">169th signatory</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ramsar_Convention" title="Ramsar Convention">Ramsar Convention</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bubiyan_Island" title="Bubiyan Island">Bubiyan Island</a>'s Mubarak al-Kabeer reserve was designated as the country's first Wetland of International Importance.<sup id="cite_ref-ramsar_287-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ramsar-287">[287]</a></sup> The 50,948&nbsp;ha reserve consists of small lagoons and shallow <a href="/wiki/Saltmarsh" class="mw-redirect" title="Saltmarsh">salt marshes</a> and is important as a stop-over for migrating birds on two migration routes.<sup id="cite_ref-ramsar_287-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ramsar-287">[287]</a></sup> The reserve is home to the world's largest breeding colony of <a href="/wiki/Crab-plover" title="Crab-plover">crab-plover</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ramsar_287-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ramsar-287">[287]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Biodiversity">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Kuwait" title="Wildlife of Kuwait">Wildlife of Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>More than 363 species of birds were recorded in Kuwait, 18 species of which breed in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-bsc-eoc_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bsc-eoc-288">[288]</a></sup> Kuwait is situated at the crossroads of several major bird migration routes and between two and three million birds pass each year.<sup id="cite_ref-natstrat_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natstrat-289">[289]</a></sup> The marshes in northern Kuwait and Jahra have become increasingly important as a refuge for passage migrants.<sup id="cite_ref-natstrat_289-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natstrat-289">[289]</a></sup> Kuwaiti islands are important breeding areas for four species of <a href="/wiki/Tern" title="Tern">tern</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Socotra_cormorant" title="Socotra cormorant">socotra cormorant</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natstrat_289-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natstrat-289">[289]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait's marine and littoral ecosystems contain the bulk of the country's biodiversity heritage.<sup id="cite_ref-natstrat_289-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natstrat-289">[289]</a></sup> Twenty eight species of mammal are found in Kuwait; animals such as gerboa, desert rabbits and <a href="/wiki/Hedgehog" title="Hedgehog">hedgehogs</a> are common in the desert.<sup id="cite_ref-natstrat_289-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natstrat-289">[289]</a></sup> Large carnivores, such as the <a href="/wiki/Wolf" title="Wolf">wolf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caracal" title="Caracal">caracal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jackal" title="Jackal">jackal</a>, are not found.<sup id="cite_ref-natstrat_289-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natstrat-289">[289]</a></sup> Among the endangered mammalian species are the <a href="/wiki/Red_fox" title="Red fox">red fox</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wild_cat" class="mw-redirect" title="Wild cat">wild cat</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natstrat_289-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natstrat-289">[289]</a></sup> Causes for wildlife extinction are habitat destruction and extensive unregulated hunting.<sup id="cite_ref-natstrat_289-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natstrat-289">[289]</a></sup> Forty reptile species have been recorded although none are endemic to Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-natstrat_289-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natstrat-289">[289]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_and_sanitation">Water and sanitation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Water and sanitation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Kuwait is part of the <a href="/wiki/Tigris%E2%80%93Euphrates_river_system" title="Tigris–Euphrates river system">Tigris–Euphrates river system</a> basin.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-eu_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eu-293">[293]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-eb_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eb-294">[294]</a></sup> Several Tigris–Euphrates <a href="/wiki/Confluence" title="Confluence">confluences</a> form parts of the Kuwait–Iraq border.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup> Kuwait does not currently have any permanent rivers within its territory. However, Kuwait does have several <a href="/wiki/List_of_wadis_of_Kuwait" title="List of wadis of Kuwait">wadis</a>, the most notable of which is <a href="/wiki/Wadi_Al-Batin" title="Wadi Al-Batin">Wadi Al-Batin</a> which forms the border between Kuwait and Iraq.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup> Kuwait also has several river-like marine channels around <a href="/wiki/Bubiyan_Island" title="Bubiyan Island">Bubiyan Island</a>, most notably <a href="/wiki/Khawr_Abd_Allah" title="Khawr Abd Allah">Khawr Abd Allah</a> which is now an <a href="/wiki/Estuary" title="Estuary">estuary</a>, but once was the point where the <a href="/wiki/Shatt_al-Arab" title="Shatt al-Arab">Shatt al-Arab</a> emptied into the Persian Gulf. Khawr Abd Allah is located in southern Iraq and northern Kuwait, the <a href="/wiki/Iraq-Kuwait_border" class="mw-redirect" title="Iraq-Kuwait border">Iraq-Kuwait border</a> divides the lower portion of the estuary, but adjacent to the port of <a href="/wiki/Umm_Qasr" title="Umm Qasr">Umm Qasr</a> the estuary becomes wholly Iraqi. It forms the northeast coastline of Bubiyan Island and the north coastline of <a href="/wiki/Warbah_Island" title="Warbah Island">Warbah Island</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EB_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB-297">[297]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait relies on water <a href="/wiki/Desalination" title="Desalination">desalination</a> as a primary source of fresh water for drinking and domestic purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-scidi_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scidi-298">[298]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fao_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fao-299">[299]</a></sup> There are currently more than six desalination plants.<sup id="cite_ref-fao_299-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fao-299">[299]</a></sup> Kuwait was the first country in the world to use desalination to supply water for large-scale domestic use. The history of desalination in Kuwait dates back to 1951 when the first distillation plant was commissioned.<sup id="cite_ref-scidi_298-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scidi-298">[298]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1965, the Kuwaiti government commissioned the Swedish engineering company of VBB (<a href="/wiki/Sweco" title="Sweco">Sweco</a>) to develop and implement a plan for a modern <a href="/wiki/Water-supply_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Water-supply system">water-supply system</a> for Kuwait City. The company built <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Water_Towers" title="Kuwait Water Towers">five groups of water towers</a>, thirty-one towers total, designed by its chief architect <a href="/wiki/Sune_Lindstr%C3%B6m" title="Sune Lindström">Sune Lindström</a>, called "the mushroom towers". For a sixth site, the Emir of Kuwait, Sheikh <a href="/wiki/Jaber_al-Ahmad_al-Jaber_al-Sabah" class="mw-redirect" title="Jaber al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah">Jaber Al-Ahmed</a>, wanted a more spectacular design. This last group, known as <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Towers" title="Kuwait Towers">Kuwait Towers</a>, consists of three towers, two of which also serve as water towers.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup> Water from the desalination facility is pumped up to the tower. The thirty-three towers have a standard capacity of 102,000 cubic meters of water. "The Water Towers" (Kuwait Tower and the Kuwait Water Towers) were awarded the <a href="/wiki/Aga_Khan_Award_for_Architecture" title="Aga Khan Award for Architecture">Aga Khan Award for Architecture</a> (1980 Cycle).<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait's fresh water resources are limited to groundwater, desalinated seawater, and treated wastewater effluents.<sup id="cite_ref-scidi_298-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scidi-298">[298]</a></sup> There are three major municipal wastewater treatment plants.<sup id="cite_ref-scidi_298-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scidi-298">[298]</a></sup> Most water demand is currently satisfied through seawater desalination plants.<sup id="cite_ref-scidi_298-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scidi-298">[298]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fao_299-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fao-299">[299]</a></sup> Sewage disposal is handled by a national sewage network that covers 98% of facilities in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Government">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Kuwait" title="Cabinet of Kuwait">Cabinet of Kuwait</a>, <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Kuwait" title="Government of Kuwait">Government of Kuwait</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Kuwait" title="Politics of Kuwait">Politics of Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_system">Political system</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Political system">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Kuwait is an emirate with an <a href="/wiki/Autocratic" class="mw-redirect" title="Autocratic">autocratic</a> political system,<sup id="cite_ref-:4_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-18">[18]</a></sup> which is sometimes described as "<a href="/wiki/Semi-democracy" class="mw-redirect" title="Semi-democracy">semi-democratic</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Emir_of_Kuwait" title="Emir of Kuwait">Emir</a> is the head of state. The political system consists of an <a href="/wiki/Legal_system_of_Kuwait" title="Legal system of Kuwait">appointed judiciary</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Kuwait" title="Cabinet of Kuwait">appointed government</a> (dominated by the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Al_Sabah" title="House of Al Sabah">Al Sabah</a> ruling family), and <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Kuwait)" title="National Assembly (Kuwait)">nominally elected parliament</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_18-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-18">[18]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Kuwait" title="Constitution of Kuwait">Constitution of Kuwait</a> was promulgated in 1962. The Emir has autocratically suspended the constitution twice: in 1976 and 1986.<sup id="cite_ref-loc_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-loc-304">[304]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:4_18-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-18">[18]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> rates the country as "Partly Free" in the <a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World" title="Freedom in the World">Freedom in the World</a> survey,<sup id="cite_ref-FH2011_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FH2011-305">[305]</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Polity_data_series" title="Polity data series">Polity data series</a><sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[308]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">Economist</a> <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a><sup id="cite_ref-autocracy2_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autocracy2-309">[309]</a></sup> both categorise Kuwait as an <a href="/wiki/Autocracy" title="Autocracy">autocracy</a> (<a href="/wiki/Dictatorship" title="Dictatorship">dictatorship</a>). </p>
      <p>Kuwait is regularly characterized as being a "<a href="/wiki/Rentier_state" title="Rentier state">rentier state</a>" in which the ruling family uses oil revenues to buy the political acquiescence of the citizenry. Although Kuwait's political system is autocratic,<sup id="cite_ref-:4_18-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-18">[18]</a></sup> the Constitution of Kuwait is considered the most liberal constitution in the GCC.<sup id="cite_ref-lse_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lse-310">[310]</a></sup> It theoretically guarantees a wide range of civil liberties to Kuwaiti citizens. Kuwait has an active <a href="/wiki/Public_sphere" title="Public sphere">public sphere</a> and <a href="/wiki/Civil_society" title="Civil society">civil society</a> with political and social organizations that are parties in all but name.<sup id="cite_ref-rubin_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rubin-311">[311]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-greo_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-greo-312">[312]</a></sup> Professional groups like the <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Chamber_of_Commerce_and_Industry" title="Kuwait Chamber of Commerce and Industry">Chamber of Commerce</a> maintain their autonomy from the government.<sup id="cite_ref-rubin_311-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rubin-311">[311]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-greo_312-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-greo-312">[312]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Seifpalace.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Seifpalace.jpg/220px-Seifpalace.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Seifpalace.jpg/330px-Seifpalace.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Seifpalace.jpg/440px-Seifpalace.jpg 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="653"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Seifpalace.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Seif_Palace" title="Seif Palace">Seif Palace</a>, the original seat of the Government of Kuwait.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Executive power is executed by the government.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_18-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-18">[18]</a></sup> The Emir appoints the prime minister, who in turn chooses the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Kuwait" title="Cabinet of Kuwait">cabinet of ministers</a> comprising the government. In recent decades, numerous policies of the Kuwaiti government have been characterized as "<a href="/wiki/Demographic_engineering" title="Demographic engineering">demographic engineering</a>", especially in relation to Kuwait's <a href="/wiki/Bedoon#Kuwait" title="Bedoon">stateless Bedoon crisis</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kuwaiti_nationality_law#History_of_naturalization_in_Kuwait" title="Kuwaiti nationality law">history of naturalization</a> in Kuwait. </p>
      <p>The judiciary is not independent of the government,<sup id="cite_ref-:4_18-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-18">[18]</a></sup> the Emir appoints all the judges and many judges are foreign nationals from <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>. The Constitutional Court is charged with ruling on the conformity of laws and decrees with the constitution. </p>
      <p>The legislative branch consists of the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Kuwait)" title="National Assembly (Kuwait)">National Assembly</a>, which has nominal oversight authority. The Emir can autocratically dissolve the parliament.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_18-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-18">[18]</a></sup> Since the 1960s, more than 60% of all Kuwaiti parliaments have been dissolved by the Emir without completing the full four-year term.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_18-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-18">[18]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Although Kuwaiti women outnumber men in the workforce,<sup id="cite_ref-gnw_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gnw-25">[25]</a></sup> the political participation of <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Kuwait" title="Women in Kuwait">Kuwaiti women</a> has been limited.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[313]</a></sup> Kuwaiti women are considered among the most emancipated women in the Middle East. In 2014 and 2015, Kuwait was ranked first among Arab countries in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Gender_Gap_Report" title="Global Gender Gap Report">Global Gender Gap Report</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hgh_177-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hgh-177">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wid_178-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wid-178">[178]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wef_179-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wef-179">[179]</a></sup> In 2013, 53% of Kuwaiti women participated in the labor force.<sup id="cite_ref-gend_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gend-26">[26]</a></sup> Kuwait has higher female citizen participation in the workforce than other GCC countries.<sup id="cite_ref-gnw_25-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gnw-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-gend_26-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gend-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwaiti law does not recognize political parties. However, several political groups function as <i>de facto</i> political parties. Major <i>de facto</i> political parties include the <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance_(Kuwait)" title="National Democratic Alliance (Kuwait)">National Democratic Alliance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Popular_Action_Bloc" title="Popular Action Bloc">Popular Action Bloc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hadas" title="Hadas">Hadas</a> (Kuwaiti <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Brotherhood" title="Muslim Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a>), <a href="/wiki/National_Islamic_Alliance" title="National Islamic Alliance">National Islamic Alliance</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Peace_Alliance" title="Justice and Peace Alliance">Justice and Peace Alliance</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Foreign relations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Kuwait" title="Foreign relations of Kuwait">Foreign relations of Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_of_Kuwait.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Diplomatic_missions_of_Kuwait.png/400px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Kuwait.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="175" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Diplomatic_missions_of_Kuwait.png/600px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Kuwait.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Diplomatic_missions_of_Kuwait.png/800px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Kuwait.png 2x" data-file-width="1425" data-file-height="625"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_of_Kuwait.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Location of diplomatic missions of Kuwait: 
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#ED1C24; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Kuwait
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#000080; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Embassy
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The foreign affairs of Kuwait are handled at the level of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Kuwait)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Kuwait)">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a>. The first foreign affairs department bureau was established in 1961. Kuwait became the 111th member state of the United Nations in May 1963. It is a long-standing member of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Cooperation_Council" title="Gulf Cooperation Council">Gulf Cooperation Council</a>. </p>
      <p>Before the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a>, Kuwait was the only "pro-<a href="/wiki/Soviet" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet">Soviet</a>" state in the Persian Gulf region.<sup id="cite_ref-russ_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-russ-315">[315]</a></sup> Kuwait acted as a conduit for the Soviets to the other Arab states of the Persian Gulf, and Kuwait was used to demonstrate the benefits of a pro-Soviet stance.<sup id="cite_ref-russ_315-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-russ-315">[315]</a></sup> In July 1987, Kuwait refused to allow U.S. military bases in its territory.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[316]</a></sup> As a result of the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a>, Kuwait's relations with the U.S. have improved (<a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">major non-NATO ally</a>) and it currently hosts thousands of <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">US military personnel</a> and contractors within active U.S. facilities. Kuwait is also a major ally of <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">ASEAN</a> and enjoys a close relationship with China while working to establish a model of cooperation in numerous fields.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-317">[317]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto1_318-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-318">[318]</a></sup> According to Kuwaiti officials, Kuwait is the largest Arab investor in Germany, particularly with regard to the <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a> company.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Military">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Military_of_Kuwait" class="mw-redirect" title="Military of Kuwait">Military of Kuwait</a> traces its original roots to the Kuwaiti cavalrymen and infantrymen that used to protect Kuwait and its wall since the early 1900s. These cavalrymen and infantrymen formed the defense and security forces in metropolitan areas and were charged with protecting outposts outside the wall of Kuwait. </p>
      <p>The Military of Kuwait consists of several joint defense forces. The governing bodies are the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Kuwait)" title="Ministry of Defense (Kuwait)">Kuwait Ministry of Defense</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_(Kuwait)" title="Ministry of Interior (Kuwait)">Kuwait Ministry of Interior</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_National_Guard" title="Kuwait National Guard">Kuwait National Guard</a> and the Kuwait Fire Service Directorate. The <a href="/wiki/Emir_of_Kuwait" title="Emir of Kuwait">Emir of Kuwait</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of all defense forces by default. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_system">Legal system</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Legal system">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Legal_system_of_Kuwait" title="Legal system of Kuwait">Legal system of Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait follows the "<a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law system</a>" modeled after the French legal system,<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[321]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup> Kuwait's legal system is largely secular.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[323]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hopkins_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hopkins-324">[324]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[325]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[326]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> law governs only <a href="/wiki/Family_law" title="Family law">family law</a> for Muslim residents,<sup id="cite_ref-hopkins_324-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hopkins-324">[324]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[327]</a></sup> while non-Muslims in Kuwait have a secular family law. For the application of <a href="/wiki/Family_law" title="Family law">family law</a>, there are three separate court sections: <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni</a> (<a href="/wiki/Maliki" title="Maliki">Maliki</a>), <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dhimmi" title="Dhimmi">non-Muslim</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, Kuwait's legal system is a mix of <a href="/wiki/English_law#Common_law" title="English law">English common law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Law_of_France" title="Law of France">French civil law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Civil_Code" title="Egyptian Civil Code">Egyptian civil law</a> and Islamic law.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[328]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">court system</a> in Kuwait is secular.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[329]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ipo_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ipo-330">[330]</a></sup> Unlike other <a href="/wiki/Arab_states_of_the_Persian_Gulf" title="Arab states of the Persian Gulf">Arab states of the Persian Gulf</a>, Kuwait does not have Sharia courts.<sup id="cite_ref-ipo_330-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ipo-330">[330]</a></sup> Sections of the civil court system administer family law.<sup id="cite_ref-ipo_330-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ipo-330">[330]</a></sup> Kuwait has the most secular <a href="/wiki/Commercial_law" title="Commercial law">commercial law</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Arab_States_of_the_Persian_Gulf" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab States of the Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf region</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[331]</a></sup> The parliament criminalized alcohol consumption in 1983.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[332]</a></sup> Kuwait's <a href="/wiki/Code_of_Personal_Status_(Kuwait)" title="Code of Personal Status (Kuwait)">Code of Personal Status</a> was promulgated in 1984.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[333]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Human rights">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Kuwait" title="Human rights in Kuwait">Human rights in Kuwait</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bedoon" title="Bedoon">Bedoon</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Kuwait" title="Human rights in Kuwait">Human rights in Kuwait</a> has been the subject of significant criticism, particularly regarding the <a href="/wiki/Bedoon" title="Bedoon">Bedoon</a> (stateless people).<sup id="cite_ref-new_29-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-new-29">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-s_30-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-s-30">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mass_graves_bedoon3_334-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mass_graves_bedoon3-334">[334]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-massgravesbedoon5_167-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-massgravesbedoon5-167">[167]</a></sup> The Kuwaiti government's handling of the stateless Bedoon crisis has come under significant criticism from many human rights organisations and even the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-unitednations_335-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unitednations-335">[335]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> in 1995, Kuwait has produced 300,000 stateless Bedoon.<sup id="cite_ref-hrw_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hrw-32">[32]</a></sup> Kuwait has the largest number of stateless people in the entire region.<sup id="cite_ref-s_30-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-s-30">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-una_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-una-31">[31]</a></sup> Since 1986, the Kuwaiti government has refused to grant any form of documentation to the Bedoon including birth certificates, death certificates, identity cards, marriage certificates, and driving licences.<sup id="cite_ref-una_31-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-una-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dis_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dis-336">[336]</a></sup> The Kuwaiti Bedoon crisis resembles the <a href="/wiki/Rohingya" class="mw-redirect" title="Rohingya">Rohingya</a> crisis in <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> (Burma).<sup id="cite_ref-rights_337-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rights-337">[337]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On the other hand, human rights organizations have criticized Kuwait for the human rights abuses toward foreign nationals. Foreign nationals account for 70% of Kuwait's total population. The <a href="/wiki/Kafala_system" title="Kafala system">kafala system</a> leaves foreign nationals prone to exploitation. Administrative deportation is very common in Kuwait for minor offenses, including minor traffic violations. Kuwait is one of the world's worst offenders in <a href="/wiki/Trafficking_in_human_beings" class="mw-redirect" title="Trafficking in human beings">human trafficking</a>. Hundreds of thousands of foreign nationals are subjected to numerous human rights abuses including involuntary servitude. They are subjected to physical and sexual abuse, non-payment of wages, poor work conditions, threats, confinement to the home, and withholding of passports to restrict their freedom of movement.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[338]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[339]</a></sup> Many human rights organizations have accused Kuwait of <a href="/wiki/Apartheid" title="Apartheid">apartheid policies</a> toward foreign nationals. </p>
      <p>In 2009, 20% of the youth in juvenile centres had dyslexia, as compared to the 6% of the general population.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[340]</a></sup> Data from a 1993 study found that there is a higher rate of psychiatric morbidity in Kuwaiti prisons than in the general population.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[341]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Administrative divisions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Governorates_of_Kuwait" title="Governorates of Kuwait">Governorates of Kuwait</a> and <a href="/wiki/Areas_of_Kuwait" title="Areas of Kuwait">Areas of Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait is divided into <a href="/wiki/Governorates_of_Kuwait" title="Governorates of Kuwait">six governorates</a>: <a href="/wiki/Al_Asimah_Governorate_(Kuwait)" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Asimah Governorate (Kuwait)">Al Asimah Governorate</a> (or Capital Governorate); <a href="/wiki/Hawalli_Governorate" title="Hawalli Governorate">Hawalli Governorate</a>; <a href="/wiki/Farwaniya_Governorate" title="Farwaniya Governorate">Farwaniya Governorate</a>; <a href="/wiki/Mubarak_Al-Kabeer_Governorate" title="Mubarak Al-Kabeer Governorate">Mubarak Al-Kabeer Governorate</a>; <a href="/wiki/Ahmadi_Governorate" title="Ahmadi Governorate">Ahmadi Governorate</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Jahra_Governorate" title="Jahra Governorate">Jahra Governorate</a>. The governorates are further <a href="/wiki/Areas_of_Kuwait" title="Areas of Kuwait">subdivided into areas</a>. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Economy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Kuwait" title="Economy of Kuwait">Economy of Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwait_Export_Treemap.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Kuwait_Export_Treemap.jpg/300px-Kuwait_Export_Treemap.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="234" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Kuwait_Export_Treemap.jpg/450px-Kuwait_Export_Treemap.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Kuwait_Export_Treemap.jpg/600px-Kuwait_Export_Treemap.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2670" data-file-height="2086"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwait_Export_Treemap.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A proportional representation of Kuwait's exports in 2012.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait has a wealthy <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a>-based economy. The <a href="/wiki/Kuwaiti_dinar" title="Kuwaiti dinar">Kuwaiti dinar</a> is the highest-valued unit of currency in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-curr_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-curr-19">[19]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, Kuwait is the seventh richest country in the world <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita#List_of_countries_and_dependencies" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">per capita</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank_342-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank-342">[342]</a></sup> Kuwait is the second richest GCC country per capita (after <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank_342-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank-342">[342]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[343]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[344]</a></sup> As a result of various diversification policies, petroleum now accounts for only 43% of total GDP and 70% of export earnings.<sup id="cite_ref-newes_201-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newes-201">[201]</a></sup> Non-petroleum industries include financial services.<sup id="cite_ref-diver_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-diver-345">[345]</a></sup> Kuwait's main export products are oil and refined products, motor cars and other motor vehicles, <a href="/wiki/Lightvessels" class="mw-redirect" title="Lightvessels">lightvessels</a>, and floating cranes/docks.<sup id="cite_ref-newes_201-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newes-201">[201]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the past five years, there has been a significant rise in <a href="/wiki/Entrepreneurship" title="Entrepreneurship">entrepreneurship</a> and small business start-ups in Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[346]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[347]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Informal_sector" class="mw-redirect" title="Informal sector">informal sector</a> is also on the rise,<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup> mainly due to the popularity of Instagram businesses.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[349]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[350]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[351]</a></sup> In 2020, Kuwait ranked fourth in the MENA region in startup funding after the UAE, Egypt and Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[352]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2018 Kuwait enacted certain measures to regulate foreign labor. Citing security concerns, workers from <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a> will be subject to heightened scrutiny when applying for entry visas, and an outright ban was being imposed on the entry of domestic workers from <a href="/wiki/Guinea-Bissau" title="Guinea-Bissau">Guinea-Bissau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[353]</a></sup> Workers from <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> are also banned.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[354]</a></sup> In April 2019, Kuwait added Ethiopia, Burkina Faso, Bhutan, Guinea and Guinea-Bissau to the list of banned countries bringing the total to 20. According to Migrant Rights, the bans are put in place mainly due to the fact that these countries lack embassies and labour corporations in Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[355]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Petroleum_and_natural_gas">Petroleum and natural gas</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Petroleum and natural gas">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Petroleum_industry_in_Kuwait" title="Petroleum industry in Kuwait">Petroleum industry in Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Despite its relatively small territory, Kuwait has proven crude <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves#Countries" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves">oil reserves</a> of 104&nbsp;billion barrels, estimated to be 10% of the world's reserves. Kuwait also has substantial <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_proven_reserves" title="List of countries by natural gas proven reserves">natural gas reserves</a>. All natural resources in the country are state property. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Finance">Finance</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Finance">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Al_Hamra_Tower.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/42/Al_Hamra_Tower.jpg/220px-Al_Hamra_Tower.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="330" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/42/Al_Hamra_Tower.jpg/330px-Al_Hamra_Tower.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/42/Al_Hamra_Tower.jpg/440px-Al_Hamra_Tower.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="5472"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Al_Hamra_Tower.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Al_Hamra_Tower" title="Al Hamra Tower">Al Hamra Tower</a> is the tallest sculpted tower in the world.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Investment_Authority" title="Kuwait Investment Authority">Kuwait Investment Authority</a> (KIA) is Kuwait's <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_wealth_fund" title="Sovereign wealth fund">sovereign wealth fund</a> specializing in foreign investment. The KIA is the world's oldest sovereign wealth fund. Since 1953, the Kuwaiti government has directed investments into Europe, United States and <a href="/wiki/Asia_Pacific" class="mw-redirect" title="Asia Pacific">Asia Pacific</a>. In 2015, the holdings were valued at $592&nbsp;billion in assets.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[356]</a></sup> It is the <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_wealth_fund#Largest_sovereign_wealth_funds" title="Sovereign wealth fund">5th largest</a> sovereign wealth fund in the world. </p>
      <p>Kuwait has a leading position in the financial industry in the GCC.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> The Emir has promoted the idea that Kuwait should focus its energies, in terms of economic development, on the financial industry.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> The historical preeminence of Kuwait (among the GCC monarchies) in finance dates back to the founding of the <a href="/wiki/National_Bank_of_Kuwait" title="National Bank of Kuwait">National Bank of Kuwait</a> in 1952.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> The bank was the first local publicly traded corporation in the GCC region.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> In the late 1970s and early 1980s, an alternative stock market, trading in shares of GCC companies, emerged in Kuwait, the <a href="/wiki/Souk_Al-Manakh_stock_market_crash" title="Souk Al-Manakh stock market crash">Souk Al-Manakh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> At its peak, its market capitalization was the third highest in the world, behind only the United States and Japan, and ahead of the United Kingdom and France.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait has a large wealth-management industry that stands out in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> Kuwaiti investment companies administer more assets than those of any other GCC country, save the much larger Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> The Kuwait Financial Centre, in a rough calculation, estimated that Kuwaiti firms accounted for over one-third of the total assets under management in the GCC.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> </p>
