      <p>The relative strength of Kuwait in the financial industry extends to its stock market.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> For many years, the total valuation of <a href="/wiki/List_of_companies_of_Kuwait" title="List of companies of Kuwait">all companies</a> listed on the <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Stock_Exchange" class="mw-redirect" title="Kuwait Stock Exchange">Kuwait Stock Exchange</a> far exceeded the value of those on any other GCC bourse, except Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> In 2011, financial and banking companies made up more than half of the market capitalization of the Kuwaiti bourse; among all the GCC states, the market capitalization of Kuwaiti financial-sector firms was, in total, behind only that of Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> In recent years, Kuwaiti investment companies have invested large percentages of their assets abroad, and their foreign assets have become substantially larger than their domestic assets.<sup id="cite_ref-wages_357-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wages-357">[357]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait is a major source of foreign economic assistance to other states through the <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Fund_for_Arab_Economic_Development" title="Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development">Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development</a>, an autonomous state institution created in 1961 on the pattern of international development agencies. In 1974, the fund's lending mandate was expanded to include all <a href="/wiki/Developing_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="Developing countries">developing countries</a> in the world. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Health">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Kuwait" title="Health in Kuwait">Health in Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait has a state-funded <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Kuwait" title="Healthcare in Kuwait">healthcare system</a>, which provides treatment without charge to Kuwaiti nationals. There are outpatient clinics in every residential area in Kuwait. A public insurance scheme exists to provide reduced cost healthcare to expatriates. Private healthcare providers also run medical facilities in the country, available to members of their insurance schemes. As part of Kuwait Vision 2035, many new hospitals have opened.<sup id="cite_ref-health4_230-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health4-230">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-health5_231-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health5-231">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-health1_232-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health1-232">[232]</a></sup> In the years leading up to the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> pandemic, Kuwait invested in its health care system at a rate that was proportionally higher than most other GCC countries.<sup id="cite_ref-health3_229-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health3-229">[229]</a></sup> As a result, the public hospital sector significantly increased its capacity.<sup id="cite_ref-health4_230-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health4-230">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-health5_231-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health5-231">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-health1_232-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health1-232">[232]</a></sup> Kuwait currently has 20 <a href="/wiki/List_of_hospitals_in_Kuwait" title="List of hospitals in Kuwait">public hospitals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-health6_233-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health6-233">[233]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-health5_231-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health5-231">[231]</a></sup> The new Sheikh Jaber Al-Ahmad Hospital is the largest hospital in the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-health2_234-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health2-234">[234]</a></sup> Kuwait also has 16 private hospitals.<sup id="cite_ref-health4_230-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health4-230">[230]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Science and technology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Kuwait has a growing scientific research sector. According to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Patent_and_Trademark_Office" title="United States Patent and Trademark Office">United States Patent and Trademark Office</a>, Kuwait has registered 448 <a href="/wiki/Patents" class="mw-redirect" title="Patents">patents</a> as of 31 December 2015,<sup id="cite_ref-uspto_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uspto-358">[358]</a></sup> Kuwait is the second largest patent producer in the Arab world.<sup id="cite_ref-uspto_358-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uspto-358">[358]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-orient_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-orient-360">[360]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[361]</a></sup> Kuwait produces the largest number of patents per capita in the Arab world and <a href="/wiki/OIC" class="mw-redirect" title="OIC">OIC</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mit_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mit-362">[362]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[363]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[364]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[365]</a></sup> The government has implemented various programs to foster innovation resulting in patent rights.<sup id="cite_ref-gain_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gain-366">[366]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mit_362-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mit-362">[362]</a></sup> Between 2010 and 2016, Kuwait registered the highest growth in patents in the Arab world.<sup id="cite_ref-gain_366-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gain-366">[366]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mit_362-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mit-362">[362]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-orient_360-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-orient-360">[360]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait was the first country in the region to implement <a href="/wiki/5G" title="5G">5G</a> technology.<sup id="cite_ref-5g_248-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5g-248">[248]</a></sup> Kuwait is among the world's leading markets in 5G penetration.<sup id="cite_ref-5g_248-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5g-248">[248]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5gkw_249-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5gkw-249">[249]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Space">Space</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Space">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Kuwait has an emerging space industry which is largely driven by private sector initiatives.<sup id="cite_ref-space_247-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-space-247">[247]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Um_Alaish_4">Um Alaish 4</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Um Alaish 4">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4> 
      <p>Seven years after the launch of the world's first communications satellite, <a href="/wiki/Telstar_1" title="Telstar 1">Telstar 1</a>, Kuwait inaugurated in October 1969 the first satellite ground station in the Middle East about 70&nbsp;km north of Kuwait City in an area called "Um Alaish".<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[367]</a></sup> The Um Alaish satellite station complex housed several satellite ground stations including Um Alaish 1 (1969), Um Alaish 2 (1977), and Um Alaish 3 (1981). It provided satellite communication services in Kuwait until 1990 when it was destroyed by the Iraqi armed forces during the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[368]</a></sup> In 2019, Kuwait's Orbital Space established an amateur satellite ground station to provide free access to signals from satellites in orbit passing over Kuwait. The station was named Um Alaish 4 to continue the legacy of "Um Alaish" satellite station.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[369]</a></sup> Um Alaish 4 is member of FUNcube distributed <a href="/wiki/Ground_station" title="Ground station">ground station</a> network<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[370]</a></sup> and the Satellite Networked Open Ground Station project (<a href="/wiki/SatNOGS" title="SatNOGS">SatNOGS</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[371]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="TSCK_experiment_in_space">TSCK experiment in space</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: TSCK experiment in space">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4> 
      <p>Kuwait's Orbital Space in collaboration with the <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Scientific_Center" title="Kuwait Scientific Center">Kuwait Scientific Center</a> (TSCK) introduced for the first time in Kuwait the opportunity for students to send a science experiment to space. The objectives of this initiative was to allow students to learn about (a) how science space missions are done; (b) <a href="/wiki/Micro-g_environment" title="Micro-g environment">microgravity</a> (weightlessness) environment; (c) how to do science like a real scientist. This opportunity was made possible through Orbital Space agreement with <a href="/wiki/DreamUp" title="DreamUp">DreamUp</a> PBC and <a href="/wiki/NanoRacks" class="mw-redirect" title="NanoRacks">Nanoracks</a> LLC, which are collaborating with <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">NASA</a> under a Space Act Agreement.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[372]</a></sup> The students' experiment was named "Kuwait’s Experiment: E.coli Consuming Carbon Dioxide to Combat Climate Change".<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[373]</a></sup> The experiment was launched on <a href="/wiki/SpaceX_CRS-21" title="SpaceX CRS-21">SpaceX CRS-21</a> (SpX-21) spaceflight to the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a> (ISS) on 6 December 2020. Astronauts <a href="/wiki/Shannon_Walker" title="Shannon Walker">Shannon Walker</a> (member of the ISS <a href="/wiki/Expedition_64" title="Expedition 64">Expedition 64</a>) conducted the experiment on behalf of the students. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Code_in_Space">Code in Space</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Code in Space">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4> 
      <p>To increase awareness about current opportunities and to encourage solutions to challenges faced by the satellite industry, Kuwait's Orbital Space in collaboration with the Space Challenges Program<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[374]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/EnduroSat" title="EnduroSat">EnduroSat</a><sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[375]</a></sup> introduced an international online students programming opportunity called "Code in Space". This opportunity allows students from around the world to send and execute their own code in space.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[376]</a></sup> The code is transmitted from a satellite ground station to a <a href="/wiki/CubeSat" title="CubeSat">cubesat</a> (<a href="/wiki/Small_satellite" title="Small satellite">nanosatellite</a>) orbiting earth 500&nbsp;km (310&nbsp;mi) above sea level. The code is then executed by the satellite's onboard computer and tested under real space environment conditions. The nanosatellite is called "QMR-KWT" (Arabic: قمر الكويت) which means "Moon of Kuwait", translated from Arabic. QMR-KWT is scheduled to be launched to space in June 2021<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[377]</a></sup> on <a href="/wiki/SpaceX" title="SpaceX">SpaceX</a> <a href="/wiki/Falcon_9_Block_5" title="Falcon 9 Block 5">Falcon 9 Block 5</a> rocket. It is planned to have QMR-KWT shuttled to its final destination (<a href="/wiki/Sun-synchronous_orbit" title="Sun-synchronous orbit">Sun-synchronous orbit</a>) via Vigoride orbit transfer vehicle by <a href="/wiki/Space_tug" title="Space tug">Momentus Space</a>. QMR-KWT is Kuwait's first satellite.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[378]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Kuwait_Space_Rocket">Kuwait Space Rocket</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Kuwait Space Rocket">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Space_Rocket" title="Kuwait Space Rocket">Kuwait Space Rocket</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Space_Rocket" title="Kuwait Space Rocket">Kuwait Space Rocket</a> (KSR) is a Kuwaiti project to build and launch the first <a href="/wiki/Suborbital_spaceflight" class="mw-redirect" title="Suborbital spaceflight">suborbital</a> <a href="/wiki/Liquid-propellant_rocket" title="Liquid-propellant rocket">liquid bi-propellant rocket</a> in <a href="/wiki/Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabia">Arabia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[379]</a></sup> The project is divided into two phases with two separate vehicles: an initial testing phase with KSR-1 as a <a href="/wiki/Test_article_(aerospace)" title="Test article (aerospace)">test vehicle</a> capable of reaching an altitude of 8&nbsp;km (5.0&nbsp;mi) and a more expansive suborbital test phase with the KSR-2 planned to fly to an altitude of 100&nbsp;km (62&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[380]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:UIS_Literacy_Rate_Kuwait_population_plus15_1975_2015.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/UIS_Literacy_Rate_Kuwait_population_plus15_1975_2015.png/210px-UIS_Literacy_Rate_Kuwait_population_plus15_1975_2015.png" decoding="async" width="210" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/UIS_Literacy_Rate_Kuwait_population_plus15_1975_2015.png/315px-UIS_Literacy_Rate_Kuwait_population_plus15_1975_2015.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5e/UIS_Literacy_Rate_Kuwait_population_plus15_1975_2015.png 2x" data-file-width="399" data-file-height="318"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:UIS_Literacy_Rate_Kuwait_population_plus15_1975_2015.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Kuwait's literacy rate from 1975 to 2015.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Kuwait" title="Education in Kuwait">Education in Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait had the highest <a href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a> in the Arab world in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[381]</a></sup> The general education system consists of four levels: <a href="/wiki/Kindergarten" title="Kindergarten">kindergarten</a> (lasting for 2 years), <a href="/wiki/Primary_education" title="Primary education">primary</a> (lasting for 5 years), <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">intermediate</a> (lasting for 4 years) and <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education" title="Secondary education">secondary</a> (lasting for 3 years).<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[382]</a></sup> Schooling at primary and intermediate level is compulsory for all students aged 6 – 14. All the levels of state education, including higher education, are free.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[383]</a></sup> The public education system is undergoing a revamp due to a project in conjunction with the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-oxfordbusinessgroup_384-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oxfordbusinessgroup-384">[384]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[385]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Tourism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Kuwait" title="Tourism in Kuwait">Tourism in Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2015, tourism accounted for 1.5 percent of the <a href="/wiki/GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="GDP">GDP</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[386]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[387]</a></sup> In 2016, the tourism industry generated nearly $500&nbsp;million in revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[388]</a></sup> The annual "Hala Febrayer" festival attracts many tourists from neighboring GCC countries,<sup id="cite_ref-halafeb_389-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-halafeb-389">[389]</a></sup> and includes a variety of events including music concerts, parades, and carnivals.<sup id="cite_ref-halafeb_389-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-halafeb-389">[389]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[390]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[391]</a></sup> The festival is a month-long commemoration of the <a href="/wiki/Liberation_of_Kuwait" class="mw-redirect" title="Liberation of Kuwait">liberation of Kuwait</a>, and runs from 1 to 28 February. <a href="/wiki/Liberation_Day" title="Liberation Day">Liberation Day</a> itself is celebrated on 26 February.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[392]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Amiri_Diwan_of_Kuwait" title="Amiri Diwan of Kuwait">Amiri Diwan</a> recently inaugurated the new <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_National_Cultural_District" title="Kuwait National Cultural District">Kuwait National Cultural District</a> (KNCD), which comprises <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Abdullah_Al_Salem_Cultural_Centre" class="mw-redirect" title="Sheikh Abdullah Al Salem Cultural Centre">Sheikh Abdullah Al Salem Cultural Centre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Jaber_Al_Ahmad_Cultural_Centre" class="mw-redirect" title="Sheikh Jaber Al Ahmad Cultural Centre">Sheikh Jaber Al Ahmad Cultural Centre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Shaheed_Park" title="Al Shaheed Park">Al Shaheed Park</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Al_Salam_Palace_(Kuwait)" title="Al Salam Palace (Kuwait)">Al Salam Palace</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kncd_205-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kncd-205">[205]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kncd2_204-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kncd2-204">[204]</a></sup> With a capital cost of more than US$1&nbsp;billion, the project is one of the largest cultural investments in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-kncd_205-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kncd-205">[205]</a></sup> The Kuwait National Cultural District is a member of the <a href="/wiki/Global_Cultural_Districts_Network" title="Global Cultural Districts Network">Global Cultural Districts Network</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gcdn_42-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gcdn-42">[42]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Transport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Kuwait" title="Transport in Kuwait">Transport in Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait has an extensive and modern network of highways. <a href="/wiki/Roads_in_Kuwait" title="Roads in Kuwait">Roadways</a> extended 5,749&nbsp;km (3,572&nbsp;mi), of which 4,887&nbsp;km (3,037&nbsp;mi) is paved. There are more than two million passenger cars, and 500,000 commercial taxis, buses, and trucks in use. On major highways the maximum speed is 120&nbsp;km/h (75&nbsp;mph). Since there is no railway system in the country, most people travel by automobiles. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwait_highway.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Kuwait_highway.jpg/220px-Kuwait_highway.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Kuwait_highway.jpg/330px-Kuwait_highway.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Kuwait_highway.jpg/440px-Kuwait_highway.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3100" data-file-height="2325"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwait_highway.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A highway in Kuwait City.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The country's public transportation network consists almost entirely of bus routes. The state owned Kuwait Public Transportation Company was established in 1962. It runs local bus routes across Kuwait as well as longer distance services to other <a href="/wiki/Arab_states_of_the_Persian_Gulf" title="Arab states of the Persian Gulf">Gulf states</a>. The main private bus company is CityBus, which operates about 20 routes across the country. Another private bus company, Kuwait Gulf Link Public Transport Services, was started in 2006. It runs local bus routes across Kuwait and longer distance services to neighbouring Arab countries. </p>
      <p>There are two airports in Kuwait. <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_International_Airport" title="Kuwait International Airport">Kuwait International Airport</a> serves as the principal hub for international air travel. State-owned <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Airways" title="Kuwait Airways">Kuwait Airways</a> is the largest airline in the country. A portion of the airport complex is designated as Al Mubarak Air Base, which contains the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Air_Force" title="Kuwait Air Force">Kuwait Air Force</a>, as well as the Kuwait Air Force Museum. In 2004, the first private airline of Kuwait, <a href="/wiki/Jazeera_Airways" title="Jazeera Airways">Jazeera Airways</a>, was launched. In 2005, the second private airline, <a href="/wiki/Wataniya_Airways" title="Wataniya Airways">Wataniya Airways</a> was founded. </p>
      <p>Kuwait has one of the largest shipping industries in the region. The Kuwait Ports Public Authority manages and operates ports across Kuwait. The country's principal commercial seaports are <a href="/wiki/Shuwaikh" title="Shuwaikh">Shuwaikh</a> and Shuaiba, which handled combined cargo of 753,334 TEU in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[393]</a></sup> Mina Al-Ahmadi, the largest port in the country, handles most of Kuwait's oil exports.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[394]</a></sup> Construction of <a href="/wiki/Mubarak_Al_Kabeer_Port" title="Mubarak Al Kabeer Port">Mubarak Al Kabeer Port</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bubiyan_Island" title="Bubiyan Island">Bubiyan Island</a> started in 2019. The port is expected to handle 1.3&nbsp;million <a href="/wiki/Twenty-foot_equivalent_unit" title="Twenty-foot equivalent unit">TEU</a> when operations start. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Demographics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Kuwait" title="Demographics of Kuwait">Demographics of Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwaityouth5020.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Kuwaityouth5020.jpg/220px-Kuwaityouth5020.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Kuwaityouth5020.jpg/330px-Kuwaityouth5020.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Kuwaityouth5020.jpg/440px-Kuwaityouth5020.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4256" data-file-height="2832"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwaityouth5020.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Kuwaiti youth celebrating Kuwait's independence and liberation, 2011.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait's 2018 population was 4.6&nbsp;million people, of which 1.4&nbsp;million were Kuwaitis, 1.2&nbsp;million are other Arabs, 1.8&nbsp;million Asian expatriates,<sup id="cite_ref-PACI_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PACI-2">[2]</a></sup> and 47,227 Africans.<sup id="cite_ref-gulfnews.com_395-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gulfnews.com-395">[395]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Ethnic groups">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Expatriates_in_Kuwait" title="Expatriates in Kuwait">Expatriates in Kuwait</a> account for around 70% of Kuwait's total population. At the end of December 2018, 57.65% of Kuwait's total population were <a href="/wiki/Arabs" title="Arabs">Arabs</a> (including Arab expats).<sup id="cite_ref-PACI_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PACI-2">[2]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Indian_people" title="Indian people">Indians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Egyptians" title="Egyptians">Egyptians</a> are the largest expat communities respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[396]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Religion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Kuwait" title="Religion in Kuwait">Religion in Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait's official state religion is <a href="/wiki/Maliki" title="Maliki">Maliki</a> Sunni Islam. The <a href="/wiki/Al_Sabah" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Sabah">Al Sabah</a> ruling family including the Emir, adhere to the <a href="/wiki/Maliki" title="Maliki">Maliki madhhab</a> of Sunni Islam. Most Kuwaiti citizens are Muslim; there is no official national census but it is estimated that 60%–70% are Sunni and 30%–40% are Shia.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[397]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ssi_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ssi-398">[398]</a></sup> The country includes a <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Kuwait#Kuwaiti_Christians" title="Christianity in Kuwait">native Christian</a> community, estimated to be composed of between 259 and 400 Christian Kuwaiti citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-ref_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ref-399">[399]</a></sup> Kuwait is the only <a href="/wiki/Cooperation_Council_for_the_Arab_States_of_the_Gulf" class="mw-redirect" title="Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf">GCC country</a> besides Bahrain to have a local Christian population who hold citizenship. There is also a small number of Kuwaiti citizens who follow the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="Baháʼí Faith">Baháʼí Faith</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-irfr2007_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-irfr2007-400">[400]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[401]</a></sup> Kuwait also has a large community of expatriate <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hindus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhists</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-irfr2007_400-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-irfr2007-400">[400]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Languages">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Kuwaiti_Arabic" title="Kuwaiti Arabic">Kuwaiti Arabic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kuwaiti_Persian" title="Kuwaiti Persian">Kuwaiti Persian</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait's official language is <a href="/wiki/Modern_Standard_Arabic" title="Modern Standard Arabic">Modern Standard Arabic</a>, but its everyday usage is limited to journalism and education. <a href="/wiki/Kuwaiti_Arabic" title="Kuwaiti Arabic">Kuwaiti Arabic</a> is the variant of Arabic used in everyday life.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[402]</a></sup> English is widely understood and often used as a business language. Besides English, French is taught as a third language for the students of the <a href="/wiki/Humanities" title="Humanities">humanities</a> at schools, but for two years only. Kuwaiti Arabic is a variant of <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Arabic" title="Gulf Arabic">Gulf Arabic</a>, sharing similarities with the dialects of neighboring coastal areas in Eastern Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[403]</a></sup> Due to immigration during its pre-oil history as well as trade, Kuwaiti Arabic borrowed a lot of words from <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_India" title="Languages of India">Indian languages</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balochi_language" title="Balochi language">Balochi language</a>, Turkish, English and Italian.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[404]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Due to historical immigration, <a href="/wiki/Kuwaiti_Persian" title="Kuwaiti Persian">Kuwaiti Persian</a> is used among <a href="/wiki/%27Ajam_of_Kuwait" title="'Ajam of Kuwait">Ajam Kuwaitis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[405]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[406]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Iranian_languages" title="Iranian languages">Iranian</a> sub-dialects of <a href="/wiki/Larestani" class="mw-redirect" title="Larestani">Larestani</a>, Khonji, Bastaki and Gerashi also influenced the vocabulary of Kuwaiti Arabic.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[407]</a></sup> Most Shia Kuwaiti citizens are of Iranian ancestry.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[408]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[409]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[410]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[411]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[412]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[413]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Kuwait" title="Culture of Kuwait">Culture of Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwaiti <a href="/wiki/Popular_culture" title="Popular culture">popular culture</a>, in the form of theatre, radio, music, and television soap opera, flourishes and is even exported to neighboring states.<sup id="cite_ref-cliv_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cliv-43">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[414]</a></sup> Within the Gulf Arab states, the culture of Kuwait is the closest to the culture of <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a>; this is evident in the close association between the two states in theatrical productions and soap operas.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[415]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Society">Society</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Society">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Kuwaiti society is markedly more <a href="/wiki/Open_society" title="Open society">open</a> than other Gulf Arab societies.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[416]</a></sup> Kuwaiti citizens are ethnically diverse, consisting of both Arabs and <a href="/wiki/%27Ajam_of_Kuwait" title="'Ajam of Kuwait">Persians ('Ajam)</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-venez2_417-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-venez2-417">[417]</a></sup> Kuwait stands out in the region as the most liberal in empowering women in the public sphere.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[418]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[419]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[420]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Kuwait" title="Women in Kuwait">Kuwaiti women</a> outnumber men in the workforce.<sup id="cite_ref-gnw_25-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gnw-25">[25]</a></sup> Kuwaiti political scientist Ghanim Alnajjar sees these qualities as a manifestation of Kuwaiti society as a whole, whereby in the Gulf Arab region it is "the least strict about traditions".<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[421]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Television_and_theatre">Television and theatre</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Television and theatre">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Abdulhussain_Abdulredha_2009_(cropped)_version.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Abdulhussain_Abdulredha_2009_%28cropped%29_version.jpg/220px-Abdulhussain_Abdulredha_2009_%28cropped%29_version.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="243" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/67/Abdulhussain_Abdulredha_2009_%28cropped%29_version.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="241" data-file-height="266"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Abdulhussain_Abdulredha_2009_(cropped)_version.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Abdulhussain_Abdulredha" title="Abdulhussain Abdulredha">Abdulhussain Abdulredha</a>, the most prominent Kuwaiti actor.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait's television drama industry tops other Gulf Arab drama industries and produces a minimum of fifteen serials annually.<sup id="cite_ref-omn_422-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-omn-422">[422]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ahma_423-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ahma-423">[423]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[424]</a></sup> Kuwait is the production centre of the Gulf television drama and comedy scene.<sup id="cite_ref-ahma_423-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ahma-423">[423]</a></sup> Most Gulf television drama and comedy productions are filmed in Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-ahma_423-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ahma-423">[423]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[425]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[426]</a></sup> Kuwaiti soap operas are the most-watched soap operas from the Gulf region.<sup id="cite_ref-omn_422-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-omn-422">[422]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fattah_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fattah-427">[427]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[428]</a></sup> Soap operas are most popular during the time of <a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">Ramadan</a>, when families gather to break their fast.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[429]</a></sup> Although usually performed in the <a href="/wiki/Kuwaiti_Arabic" title="Kuwaiti Arabic">Kuwaiti dialect</a>, they have been shown with success as far away as <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[430]</a></sup> Kuwait is frequently dubbed the "<a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> of the Gulf" due to the popularity of its television soap operas and theatre.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[431]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait is known for its home-grown tradition of <a href="/wiki/Theatre" title="Theatre">theatre</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hammond_432-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hammond-432">[432]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[433]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[434]</a></sup> Kuwait is the only country in the Gulf Arab region with a theatrical tradition.<sup id="cite_ref-hammond_432-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hammond-432">[432]</a></sup> The theatrical movement in Kuwait constitutes a major part of the country's cultural life.<sup id="cite_ref-theat_435-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-theat-435">[435]</a></sup> Theatrical activities in Kuwait began in the 1920s when the first spoken dramas were released.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[436]</a></sup> Theatre activities are still popular today.<sup id="cite_ref-theat_435-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-theat-435">[435]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Abdulhussain_Abdulredha" title="Abdulhussain Abdulredha">Abdulhussain Abdulredha</a> is the most prominent actor. </p>
      <p>Kuwait is the main centre of <a href="/wiki/Scenography" title="Scenography">scenographic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Performing_arts_education" title="Performing arts education">theatrical training</a> in the Gulf region.<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[437]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-thae_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thae-438">[438]</a></sup> In 1973, the Higher Institute of Theatrical Arts was founded by the government to provide <a href="/wiki/Higher_education" title="Higher education">higher education</a> in theatrical arts.<sup id="cite_ref-thae_438-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thae-438">[438]</a></sup> The institute has several divisions. Many actors have graduated from the institute, such as <a href="/wiki/Souad_Abdullah" title="Souad Abdullah">Souad Abdullah</a>, Mohammed Khalifa, <a href="/wiki/Mansour_Al-Mansour" title="Mansour Al-Mansour">Mansour Al-Mansour</a>, along with a number of prominent critics such as <a href="/wiki/Ismail_Fahd_Ismail" title="Ismail Fahd Ismail">Ismail Fahd Ismail</a>. </p>
      <p>Theatre in Kuwait is subsidized by the government, previously by the Ministry of Social Affairs and now by the National Council for Culture, Arts, and Letters (NCCAL).<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[439]</a></sup> Every urban district has a public theatre.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[440]</a></sup> The public theatre in <a href="/wiki/Salmiya" title="Salmiya">Salmiya</a> is named after Abdulhussain Abdulredha. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts">Arts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Arts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Art_of_Kuwait" title="Art of Kuwait">Art of Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait has the oldest <a href="/wiki/Modern_arts" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern arts">modern arts</a> movement in the Arabian Peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-movemnt_441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-movemnt-441">[441]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[442]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[443]</a></sup> Beginning in 1936, Kuwait was the first Gulf Arab country to grant scholarships in the arts.<sup id="cite_ref-movemnt_441-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-movemnt-441">[441]</a></sup> The Kuwaiti artist <a href="/wiki/Mojeb_al-Dousari" title="Mojeb al-Dousari">Mojeb al-Dousari</a> was the earliest recognized <a href="/wiki/Visual_artist" class="mw-redirect" title="Visual artist">visual artist</a> in the Gulf Arab region.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[444]</a></sup> He is regarded as the founder of <a href="/wiki/Portrait" title="Portrait">portrait</a> art in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">[445]</a></sup> The Sultan Gallery was the first professional Arab art gallery in the Gulf.<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">[446]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">[447]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait is home to more than <a href="/wiki/Art_of_Kuwait#Art_galleries" title="Art of Kuwait">30 art galleries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[448]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[449]</a></sup> In recent years, Kuwait's contemporary art scene has boomed.<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[450]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[451]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[452]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Khalifa_Al-Qattan" class="mw-redirect" title="Khalifa Al-Qattan">Khalifa Al-Qattan</a> was the first artist to hold a <a href="/wiki/Solo_exhibition" title="Solo exhibition">solo exhibition</a> in Kuwait. He founded a new art theory in the early 1960s known as "circulism".<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[453]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454">[454]</a></sup> Other notable Kuwaiti artists include <a href="/wiki/Sami_Mohammad" title="Sami Mohammad">Sami Mohammad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thuraya_Al-Baqsami" title="Thuraya Al-Baqsami">Thuraya Al-Baqsami</a> and <a href="/wiki/Suzan_Bushnaq" title="Suzan Bushnaq">Suzan Bushnaq</a>. </p>
      <p>The government organizes various <a href="/wiki/Arts_festivals" class="mw-redirect" title="Arts festivals">arts festivals</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Al_Qurain_Cultural_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Qurain Cultural Festival">Al Qurain Cultural Festival</a> and Formative Arts Festival.<sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455">[455]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[456]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[457]</a></sup> The Kuwait International Biennial was inaugurated in 1967,<sup id="cite_ref-biennial_458-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-biennial-458">[458]</a></sup> more than 20 Arab and foreign countries have participated in the biennial.<sup id="cite_ref-biennial_458-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-biennial-458">[458]</a></sup> Prominent participants include <a href="/wiki/Layla_Al-Attar" title="Layla Al-Attar">Layla Al-Attar</a>. In 2004, the Al Kharafi Biennial for Contemporary Arab Art was inaugurated. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Museums">Museums</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Museums">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Kuwait" title="List of museums in Kuwait">List of museums in Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Beitalsadu.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Beitalsadu.jpg/220px-Beitalsadu.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Beitalsadu.jpg/330px-Beitalsadu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Beitalsadu.jpg/440px-Beitalsadu.jpg 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="634"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Beitalsadu.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Sadu_House" title="Sadu House">Sadu House</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The new <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_National_Cultural_District" title="Kuwait National Cultural District">Kuwait National Cultural District</a> (KNCD) consists of various cultural venues including <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Abdullah_Al_Salem_Cultural_Centre" class="mw-redirect" title="Sheikh Abdullah Al Salem Cultural Centre">Sheikh Abdullah Al Salem Cultural Centre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Jaber_Al_Ahmad_Cultural_Centre" class="mw-redirect" title="Sheikh Jaber Al Ahmad Cultural Centre">Sheikh Jaber Al Ahmad Cultural Centre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Shaheed_Park" title="Al Shaheed Park">Al Shaheed Park</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Al_Salam_Palace_(Kuwait)" title="Al Salam Palace (Kuwait)">Al Salam Palace</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kncd_205-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kncd-205">[205]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kncd2_204-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kncd2-204">[204]</a></sup> With a capital cost of more than US$1&nbsp;billion, it is one of the largest cultural districts in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-kncd_205-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kncd-205">[205]</a></sup> The Abdullah Salem Cultural Centre is the largest museum complex in the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[459]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto3_212-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-212">[212]</a></sup> The Kuwait National Cultural District is a member of the <a href="/wiki/Global_Cultural_Districts_Network" title="Global Cultural Districts Network">Global Cultural Districts Network</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gcdn_42-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gcdn-42">[42]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Several Kuwaiti museums are devoted to <a href="/wiki/Islamic_art" title="Islamic art">Islamic art</a>, most notably the <a href="/wiki/Tareq_Rajab_Museum" title="Tareq Rajab Museum">Tareq Rajab Museums</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dar_al_Athar_al_Islamiyyah" title="Dar al Athar al Islamiyyah">Dar al Athar al Islamiyyah</a> cultural centres.<sup id="cite_ref-modmus_460-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-modmus-460">[460]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">[461]</a></sup> The Dar al Athar al Islamiyyah cultural centres include education wings, conservation labs, and research libraries.<sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462">[462]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[463]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dai_464-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dai-464">[464]</a></sup> There are several <a href="/wiki/Libraries" class="mw-redirect" title="Libraries">art libraries</a> in Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465">[465]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dai_464-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dai-464">[464]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[466]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Khalifa_Al-Qattan" class="mw-redirect" title="Khalifa Al-Qattan">Khalifa Al-Qattan</a>'s Mirror House is the most popular art museum in Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467">[467]</a></sup> Many museums in Kuwait are private enterprises.<sup id="cite_ref-trans_468-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trans-468">[468]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-modmus_460-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-modmus-460">[460]</a></sup> In contrast to the top-down approach in other Gulf states, museum development in Kuwait reflects a greater sense of civic identity and demonstrates the strength of civil society in Kuwait, which has produced many independent cultural enterprises.<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">[469]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-modmus_460-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-modmus-460">[460]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-trans_468-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trans-468">[468]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Sadu_House" title="Sadu House">Sadu House</a> is among Kuwait's most important cultural institutions. <a href="/wiki/Bait_Al-Othman_Museum" title="Bait Al-Othman Museum">Bait Al-Othman</a> is the largest museum specializing in Kuwait's history. <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Scientific_Center" title="Kuwait Scientific Center">The Scientific Center</a> is one of the largest science museums in the Middle East. The <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art_(Kuwait)" title="Museum of Modern Art (Kuwait)">Museum of Modern Art</a> showcases the history of modern art in Kuwait and the region.<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470">[470]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_National_Museum" title="Kuwait National Museum">National Museum</a>, established in 1983, has been described as "underused and overlooked".<sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">[471]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Music">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Kuwait" title="Music of Kuwait">Music of Kuwait</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait is the birthplace of various popular musical genres, such as <a href="/wiki/Sawt_(music)" title="Sawt (music)">sawt</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kwq_472-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kwq-472">[472]</a></sup> Kuwaiti music has considerably influenced the music culture in other <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Cooperation_Council" title="Gulf Cooperation Council">Gulf Cooperation Council</a> (GCC) countries.<sup id="cite_ref-rvo_473-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rvo-473">[473]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kwq_472-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kwq-472">[472]</a></sup> Traditional Kuwaiti music is a reflection of the country's seafaring heritage,<sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474">[474]</a></sup> which is known for genres such as <a href="/wiki/Fijiri" title="Fijiri">fijiri</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ya_Bahr_475-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ya_Bahr-475">[475]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[476]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-qdl_477-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-qdl-477">[477]</a></sup> Kuwait pioneered <a href="/wiki/Khaliji_(music)" title="Khaliji (music)">contemporary Khaliji music</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-shart_478-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shart-478">[478]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-pers_479-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pers-479">[479]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-shartw_480-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shartw-480">[480]</a></sup> Kuwaitis were the first commercial recording artists in the Gulf region.<sup id="cite_ref-shart_478-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shart-478">[478]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-pers_479-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pers-479">[479]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-shartw_480-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shartw-480">[480]</a></sup> The first known Kuwaiti recordings were made between 1912 and 1915.<sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481">[481]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Jaber_Al-Ahmad_Cultural_Centre" title="Sheikh Jaber Al-Ahmad Cultural Centre">Sheikh Jaber Al-Ahmad Cultural Centre</a> contains the largest opera house in the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482">[482]</a></sup> Kuwait is home to various <a href="/wiki/Music_festivals" class="mw-redirect" title="Music festivals">music festivals</a>, including the International Music Festival hosted by the National Council for Culture, Arts and Letters (NCCAL).<sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483">[483]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ohiol_484-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ohiol-484">[484]</a></sup> Kuwait has several academic institutions specializing in university-level <a href="/wiki/Music_education" title="Music education">music education</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-soton_485-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-soton-485">[485]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ohiocsw_486-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ohiocsw-486">[486]</a></sup> The Higher Institute of Musical Arts was established by the government to provide <a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degrees" class="mw-redirect" title="Bachelor's degrees">bachelor's degrees</a> in music.<sup id="cite_ref-ohiol2_487-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ohiol2-487">[487]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-soton_485-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-soton-485">[485]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ohiocsw_486-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ohiocsw-486">[486]</a></sup> In addition, the College of Basic Education offers bachelor's degrees in music education.<sup id="cite_ref-ohiol_484-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ohiol-484">[484]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-soton_485-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-soton-485">[485]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ohiocsw_486-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ohiocsw-486">[486]</a></sup> The Institute of Musical Studies offers degrees equivalent to <a href="/wiki/Secondary_school" title="Secondary school">secondary school</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ohiol_484-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ohiol-484">[484]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ohiocsw_486-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ohiocsw-486">[486]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-soton_485-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-soton-485">[485]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Media">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwait_Liberation_Tower_cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Kuwait_Liberation_Tower_cropped.jpg/150px-Kuwait_Liberation_Tower_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="209" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Kuwait_Liberation_Tower_cropped.jpg/225px-Kuwait_Liberation_Tower_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Kuwait_Liberation_Tower_cropped.jpg/300px-Kuwait_Liberation_Tower_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="835"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kuwait_Liberation_Tower_cropped.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The 372&nbsp;m (1,220&nbsp;ft) tall <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Telecommunications_Tower" class="mw-redirect" title="Kuwait Telecommunications Tower">Kuwait Telecommunications Tower</a> (leftmost) is the main communication tower of Kuwait.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait's media is annually classified as "partly free" in the <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_Press" class="mw-redirect" title="Freedom of Press">Freedom of Press</a> survey by Freedom House.<sup id="cite_ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488">[488]</a></sup> Since 2005,<sup id="cite_ref-prfr_489-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prfr-489">[489]</a></sup> Kuwait has frequently earned the highest ranking of all Arab countries in the annual <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a> by Reporters Without Borders.<sup id="cite_ref-fanak_490-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fanak-490">[490]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-isr_491-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-isr-491">[491]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-indi_492-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indi-492">[492]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-indextwo_493-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indextwo-493">[493]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-494" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-494">[494]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-495" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-495">[495]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-496" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-496">[496]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ofa_497-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ofa-497">[497]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-498" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-498">[498]</a></sup> In 2009, 2011, 2013 and 2014, Kuwait surpassed Israel as the country with the greatest press freedom in the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-fanak_490-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fanak-490">[490]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-isr_491-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-isr-491">[491]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-indi_492-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indi-492">[492]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-indextwo_493-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indextwo-493">[493]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ofa_497-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ofa-497">[497]</a></sup> Kuwait is also frequently ranked as the Arab country with the greatest press freedom in Freedom House's annual Freedom of Press survey.<sup id="cite_ref-lead_499-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lead-499">[499]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-500" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-500">[500]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-501" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-501">[501]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-502" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-502">[502]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-503" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-503">[503]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-504" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-504">[504]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-505" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-505">[505]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kuwait produces more <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Kuwait" title="List of newspapers in Kuwait">newspapers and magazines</a> per capita than its neighbors.<sup id="cite_ref-506" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-506">[506]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-507" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-507">[507]</a></sup> There are limits to Kuwait's press freedom; while criticism of the government and ruling family members is permitted, Kuwait's constitution criminalizes criticism of the Emir. </p>
      <p>The state-owned <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_News_Agency" title="Kuwait News Agency">Kuwait News Agency</a> (KUNA) is the largest media house in the country. The Ministry of Information regulates the media industry in Kuwait. </p>
      <p>Kuwait has 15 satellite television channels, of which four are controlled by the Ministry of Information. State-owned <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Television" title="Kuwait Television">Kuwait Television</a> (KTV) offered first colored broadcast in 1974 and operates five television channels. Government-funded Radio Kuwait also offers daily informative programming in several languages including <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a>, and English on the <a href="/wiki/AM_broadcasting" title="AM broadcasting">AM</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shortwave" class="mw-redirect" title="Shortwave">SW</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Literature">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kuwaiti_literature" title="Kuwaiti literature">Kuwaiti literature</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Kuwait has in recent years produced several prominent contemporary writers such as <a href="/wiki/Ismail_Fahd_Ismail" title="Ismail Fahd Ismail">Ismail Fahd Ismail</a>, author of over twenty novels and numerous short story collections. There is also evidence that Kuwaiti literature has long been interactive with <a href="/wiki/English_literature" title="English literature">English</a> and <a href="/wiki/French_literature" title="French literature">French literature</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-508" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-508">[508]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Sport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jaber_Al-Ahmad_International_Stadium-1.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Jaber_Al-Ahmad_International_Stadium-1.JPG/220px-Jaber_Al-Ahmad_International_Stadium-1.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Jaber_Al-Ahmad_International_Stadium-1.JPG/330px-Jaber_Al-Ahmad_International_Stadium-1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Jaber_Al-Ahmad_International_Stadium-1.JPG/440px-Jaber_Al-Ahmad_International_Stadium-1.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2016" data-file-height="1225"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jaber_Al-Ahmad_International_Stadium-1.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Jaber_Al-Ahmad_International_Stadium" title="Jaber Al-Ahmad International Stadium">Jaber Al-Ahmad International Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_City" title="Kuwait City">Kuwait City</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Football</a> is the most popular sport in Kuwait. The <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Football_Association" title="Kuwait Football Association">Kuwait Football Association</a> (KFA) is the governing body of football in Kuwait. The KFA organises the <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_national_football_team" title="Kuwait national football team">men's</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Kuwait women's national football team">women's</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Futsal" title="Futsal">futsal</a> national teams. The <a href="/wiki/Kuwaiti_Premier_League" class="mw-redirect" title="Kuwaiti Premier League">Kuwaiti Premier League</a> is the top league of Kuwaiti football, featuring eighteen teams. The <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_national_football_team" title="Kuwait national football team">Kuwait national football team</a> have been the champions of the <a href="/wiki/1980_AFC_Asian_Cup" title="1980 AFC Asian Cup">1980 AFC Asian Cup</a>, runners-up of the <a href="/wiki/1976_AFC_Asian_Cup" title="1976 AFC Asian Cup">1976 AFC Asian Cup</a>, and have taken third place of the <a href="/wiki/1984_AFC_Asian_Cup" title="1984 AFC Asian Cup">1984 AFC Asian Cup</a>. Kuwait has also been to one FIFA World Cup, in <a href="/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1982 FIFA World Cup">1982</a>; they drew 1–1 with <a href="/wiki/Czechoslovakia_national_football_team" title="Czechoslovakia national football team">Czechoslovakia</a> before losing to <a href="/wiki/France_national_football_team" title="France national football team">France</a> and <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">England</a>, failing to advance from the first round. Kuwait is home to many football clubs including <a href="/wiki/Al-Arabi_SC_(Kuwait)" title="Al-Arabi SC (Kuwait)">Al-Arabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fahaheel_(football_club)" class="mw-redirect" title="Fahaheel (football club)">Al-Fahaheel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Jahra_(football_club)" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Jahra (football club)">Al-Jahra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Kuwait_Kaifan" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Kuwait Kaifan">Al-Kuwait</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Naser_Sporting_Club" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Naser Sporting Club">Al-Naser</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Salmiya_Club" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Salmiya Club">Al-Salmiya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al-Shabab_(Kuwait)" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Shabab (Kuwait)">Al-Shabab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Qadsia_Kuwait" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Qadsia Kuwait">Al Qadsia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Yarmouk_(football_club)" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Yarmouk (football club)">Al-Yarmouk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Kazma_Kuwait" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Kazma Kuwait">Kazma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khaitan" title="Khaitan">Khaitan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sulaibikhat" title="Sulaibikhat">Sulaibikhat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sahel_(Kuwaiti_football_club)" class="mw-redirect" title="Sahel (Kuwaiti football club)">Sahel</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tadamon,_Kuwait" class="mw-redirect" title="Tadamon, Kuwait">Tadamon</a>. The biggest football rivalry in Kuwait is between <a href="/wiki/Al-Arabi_SC_(Kuwait)" title="Al-Arabi SC (Kuwait)">Al-Arabi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Al_Qadsia_Kuwait" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Qadsia Kuwait">Al Qadsia</a>. </p>
      <p>Basketball is one of the country's most popular sports. The <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Kuwait national basketball team">Kuwait national basketball team</a> is governed by the Kuwait Basketball Association (KBA). Kuwait made its international debut in 1959. The national team has been to the <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Asian_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="FIBA Asian Championship">FIBA Asian Championship</a> in basketball eleven times. The <a href="/wiki/Kuwaiti_Division_I_Basketball_League" title="Kuwaiti Division I Basketball League">Kuwaiti Division I Basketball League</a> is the highest professional basketball league in Kuwait. <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_national_cricket_team" title="Kuwait national cricket team">Cricket in Kuwait</a> is governed by the <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Cricket_Association" class="mw-redirect" title="Kuwait Cricket Association">Kuwait Cricket Association</a>. Other growing sports include <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union_in_Kuwait" title="Rugby union in Kuwait">rugby union</a>. <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_men%27s_national_handball_team" title="Kuwait men's national handball team">Handball</a> is widely considered to be the national icon of Kuwait, although football is more popular among the overall population. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Kuwait_national_ice_hockey_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Kuwait national ice hockey team">Ice hockey in Kuwait</a> is governed by the <a href="/wiki/Kuwait_Ice_Hockey_Association" title="Kuwait Ice Hockey Association">Kuwait Ice Hockey Association</a>. Kuwait first joined the <a href="/wiki/International_Ice_Hockey_Federation" title="International Ice Hockey Federation">International Ice Hockey Federation</a> in 1985, but was expelled in 1992 due to a lack of ice hockey activity.<sup id="cite_ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509">[509]</a></sup> Kuwait was re-admitted into the IIHF in May 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-510" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-510">[510]</a></sup> In 2015, Kuwait won the <a href="/wiki/IIHF_Challenge_Cup_of_Asia" title="IIHF Challenge Cup of Asia">IIHF Challenge Cup of Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-511" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-511">[511]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-512" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-512">[512]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In February 2020 Kuwait held for the first time a leg of the <a href="/wiki/Aquabike_World_Championship_(powerboating)" title="Aquabike World Championship (powerboating)">UIM Aquabike World Championship</a> in front of Marina Beach City.<sup id="cite_ref-513" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-513">[513]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r936637989">.mw-parser-output .portal{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style>
      <div role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright"> 
       <ul> 
        <li><span><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Kuwait.svg/32px-Flag_of_Kuwait.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="16" class="noviewer thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Kuwait.svg/48px-Flag_of_Kuwait.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Kuwait.svg/64px-Flag_of_Kuwait.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600"></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Kuwait" title="Portal:Kuwait">Kuwait portal</a></span></li>
       </ul>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Kuwait" title="Outline of Kuwait">Outline of Kuwait</a></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Index_of_Kuwait-related_articles" title="Index of Kuwait-related articles">Index of Kuwait-related articles</a></li>
      </ul> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuwait&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

         <li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-imf2-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-imf2_5-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-imf2_5-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-imf2_5-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-imf2_5-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2017/02/weodata/weorept.aspx?pr.x=51&amp;pr.y=15&amp;sy=2015&amp;ey=2022&amp;scsm=1&amp;ssd=1&amp;sort=country&amp;ds=.&amp;br=1&amp;c=443&amp;s=NGDPD%2CPPPGDP%2CNGDPDPC%2CPPPPC&amp;grp=0&amp;a=">"IMF Report for Selected Countries and Subjects&nbsp;: Kuwait"</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180224093441/http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2017/02/weodata/weorept.aspx?pr.x=78&amp;pr.y=12&amp;sy=2017&amp;ey=2017&amp;scsm=1&amp;ssd=1&amp;sort=country&amp;ds=.&amp;br=1&amp;c=443&amp;s=NGDPD%2CPPPGDP%2CNGDPDPC%2CPPPPC&amp;grp=0&amp;a=">Archived</a> from the original on 24 February 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 April</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=IMF+Report+for+Selected+Countries+and+Subjects+%3A+Kuwait&amp;rft.pub=International+Monetary+Fund&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.imf.org%2Fexternal%2Fpubs%2Fft%2Fweo%2F2017%2F02%2Fweodata%2Fweorept.aspx%3Fpr.x%3D51%26pr.y%3D15%26sy%3D2015%26ey%3D2022%26scsm%3D1%26ssd%3D1%26sort%3Dcountry%26ds%3D.%26br%3D1%26c%3D443%26s%3DNGDPD%252CPPPGDP%252CNGDPDPC%252CPPPPC%26grp%3D0%26a%3D&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKuwait" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-UNHDR-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-UNHDR_6-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/hdr2020.pdf"><i>Human Development Report 2020 The Next Frontier: Human Development and the Anthropocene</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. United Nations Development Programme. 15 December 2020. pp.&nbsp;343–346. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-92-1-126442-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-92-1-126442-5"><bdi>978-92-1-126442-5</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-gend-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-gend_26-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-gend_26-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-gend_26-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/scr/2013/cr13337.pdf">"Kuwait: Selected Issues"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. p.&nbsp;17. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141030072718/http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/scr/2013/cr13337.pdf">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 30 October 2014. <q>Kuwait has higher female labor market participation than other GCC countries; further improvements in labor force participation can support future growth prospects. Kuwait's labor force participation rate for Kuwaiti women (53 percent) is slightly above the world average (51 percent) and much higher than the <a href="/wiki/MENA" title="MENA">MENA</a> average (21 percent).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Kuwait%3A+Selected+Issues&amp;rft.pages=17&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.imf.org%2Fexternal%2Fpubs%2Fft%2Fscr%2F2013%2Fcr13337.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKuwait" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>
